q: What is the N+1 Query Problem?
o: Executing 1 query for a list and N more queries for related items
Use 'Eager Loading' (fetch all related data in one query)
Reusing active database connections to avoid overhead of creating new ones

Update if exists, Insert if not

Agreggates rows sharing a value into summary rows

o: Removes duplicate rows from the result set

Checks if a subquery returns any rows (True/False)

q: Which is faster to read: Clustered or Non-Clustered?
o: Clustered (usually, as data is right there)

High Cardinality columns used in WHERE/JOIN

o: Returns first non-null value from list
Lowest level, allows reading uncommitted changes (Dirty Reads)
Guarantees reading only committed data (prevents Dirty Reads)

Highest level, simulates serial execution (prevents Phantom Reads)

q: Which isolation level prevents Phantom Reads?

o: Multi-Version Concurrency Control (readers use snapshots, don't block writers)
Better concurrency (Readers don't block Writers and vice-versa)
Assume no conflict, check version at Commit
Acquire locks early to prevent conflict (block others)

To reduce Page Splits during inserts (improves write perf, reduces fragmentation)

Data page in memory that has been modified but not yet written to disk

Guarantees Atomicity and Durability (Crash Recovery uses logs)
Memory area storing data pages to reduce disk IO

Smaller size, faster maintenance, optimized for specific queries

Storing data column by column (good for compression and aggregates)

q: Why is Keyset Pagination faster than OFFSET?
o: Avoids scanning/skipping N rows (OFFSET N is O(N)); Keyset uses index seek

q: What is a 'Histogram' in DB Stats?
o: Data structure approximating distribution of values in a column (buckets)
Lock where thread busy-waits (loops) checking availability (burns CPU, fast for short waits)
Lock where thread sleeps/yields processing (context switch, good for long waits)
Lightweight synchronization object protecting shared memory structures (pages)
Multiple threads waiting for access to same in-memory page (hot page)
Least Recently Used (evict page accessed longest ago)
Approximation of LRU using a circular buffer and 'chance' bits
Most Recently Used (evict newest page, useful for one-time sequential scans)

Rewrites entire table to compact it (reclaims disk space, exclusive lock)

Partition defined by Hash(Key); Good for distribution, bad for range queries

Normal operation (no partition): choose between Latency (speed) and Consistency

q: DynamoDB uses which CAP property typically?
o: AP (Availability + Partition Tolerance) with Eventual Consistency
CP (Consistency + Partition Tolerance) - favors consistency over availability
Concurrency protocol: Expanding Phase (acquire locks) -> Shrinking Phase (release locks)
Constraint violation in Snapshot Isolation where 2 txns read consistent state but disjoint writes break invariant
Serializable Isolation, or explicit locking (SELECT ... FOR UPDATE)
Lock on all records that satisfy a WHERE clause (even non-existent ones, prevents Phantoms)
Combination of Record Lock and Gap Lock (locks index record + gap before it)
Lock on gap between index records (prevents insertion into gap -> prevents Phantoms)

Returns rows from left table where NO match exists in right (NOT EXISTS)

Very fast bitwise operations (AND/OR/NOT) for complex filtering on low cardinality data
Expensive to update (lock granularity issues, whole bitmap segment locked)

Backup of changes since last Full Backup
Backup of active transaction log (allows point-in-time restore, truncates log)

q: What happens if Log Backup is skipped?
o: Transaction Log grows indefinitely (Full Recovery Model) until disk full
Logs truncated automatically after checkpoint (No point-in-time restore)
Minimally logs bulk operations (faster bulk load, limited point-in-time)
